items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 7:00pm tonight, Sunday 5th October, and for at least the next 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are currently monitoring the situation and will update this message if necessary. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. Levels may reach Flood Alert again throughout the week due to a set of spring tides, we will update this message as necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 02:15 on 06/10/25 and 4.14 mAOD at 15:00 on 06/10/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 11 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 06/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Aire catchment
items.message: The flood alert has been removed; the levels have fallen an there is no further significant rainfall expected.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Levels are now below flood risk thresholds. The following tide on Monday 06 October 2025 at 06:45 am is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The previous Flood Alert in force for this morning’s tide has now been removed.  Further high tides are predicted for Wednesday 8 October and Thursday 9 October, and there is a possibility further Flood Alerts could be issued in relation to these tides during the coming week.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next couple of days. We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels are receding but remain above the flood alert level .
Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high and are starting to slowly recede following recent heavy rain.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
No further flooding is expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely. It is possible that we will issue further flood alerts over the next few days.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high and are starting to recede following Storm Amy. 
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site .
There may be some isolated showers throughout today, Monday 06/10/25.
We are continuing to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 07/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
